title: Rational number
summary: In mathematics, a rational number is a number that can be expressed as the quotient or fraction p q {\displaystyle {\tfrac {p}{q}}} of two integers, a numerator p and a non-zero denominator q.[1] For example, âˆ’ 3 7 {\displaystyle {\tfrac {-3}{7}}} is a rational number, as is every integer (e.g. 5 = 5/1). The set of all rational numbers, also referred to as "the rationals",[2] the field of rationals[3] or the field of rational numbers is usually denoted by boldface Q,[4] or blackboard bold Q . {\displaystyle \mathbb {Q} .} [5]
